countries.name: Portugal
countries.summary:
Portugal is having a moment, and it's simultaneously wonderful and worrying. Tourism is booming—30 million visitors in 2024, up from 27 million in 2023, for a country of 10.3 million people. Lisbon and Porto are packed with digital nomads, retirees, and tourists. Tech investment is flowing—startups raised €1.5 billion in 2024, and Lisbon is branding itself as Europe's next startup hub. GDP growth was 2.3% in 2024, and unemployment fell to 6.5%, the lowest in two decades. But underneath the gleam, there's a crisis: housing. Rents and house prices have soared, making Lisbon unaffordable for locals. A one-bedroom apartment in Lisbon averages €1,400/month; the median salary is €1,200. Young Portuguese are emigrating—again—to France, Luxembourg, and the UK, chasing wages that can afford housing. Portugal is gentrifying itself.

The economic recovery post-2010s debt crisis is real. In 2011, Portugal needed a €78 billion EU-IMF bailout, similar to Greece. Unemployment hit 17%, wages were cut, the economy contracted. It was brutal. By 2025, public debt is down to 99% of GDP from a peak of 135%, the fiscal deficit is 0.8%—basically balanced—and Portugal has regained investment-grade credit ratings. The turnaround is legit. But the composition of growth is lopsided. Services are 75% of GDP, driven by tourism, tech, and real estate. Manufacturing is 13%, down from 20% in 2000. Industry has hollowed out; textiles, footwear, and shipbuilding—once pillars—have shrunk. Portugal is a service economy, and service economies are volatile.

Tourism is the double-edged sword. The sector contributes 15% of GDP directly, more including indirect effects, and employs 900,000 people. It's been a lifesaver—tourism revenues hit €25 billion in 2024, up from €18 billion in 2019. Portugal has gorgeous beaches, historic cities, great wine, and crucially, it's safe and sunny. Americans, Brits, Germans, and French flood in. But the model is straining infrastructure. Lisbon's metro is overcrowded. Short-term rentals (Airbnb) have swallowed housing stock—20,000 units in Lisbon alone are listed on platforms, removed from the long-term rental market. The government banned new licenses in urban areas in 2024, but enforcement is weak. Locals resent being priced out of neighborhoods transformed into tourist zones. Anti-tourism protests erupted in Porto in 2024, echoing Barcelona's backlash.

Housing is the political crisis. House prices in Lisbon rose 150% between 2015 and 2024. In Porto, 120%. Average salaries rose 30%. The math doesn't work. Young Portuguese can't buy homes; they can't even afford rent. The fertility rate is 1.4, partially because people can't afford space for children. The government, under center-right Prime Minister Luís Montenegro (elected 2024), has pledged a housing plan—build 100,000 affordable units, limit short-term rentals, offer tax breaks for renters. But execution is slow, and local opposition blocks construction. NIMBYism is strong; neighborhoods resist densification. Portugal has a housing crisis but won't build its way out because politics and regulation block it.

The tech sector is the bright spot. Lisbon's Web Summit, one of Europe's largest tech conferences, attracts 70,000 attendees annually. Unicorns like Talkdesk (AI customer service) and Outsystems (low-code platforms) are Portuguese-founded. The government offers tax breaks for startups and foreign talent—the D7 visa for remote workers and the NHR (Non-Habitual Resident) tax regime, which gave new residents a decade of reduced taxes. NHR was reformed in 2024 under pressure—it was accused of inflating housing costs by attracting wealthy expats—but tech investment continues. The challenge is scaling. Portugal's domestic market is small, so startups must internationalize early, which is risky. And Portuguese VCs are undercapitalized compared to UK or German funds.

Demographics are grim. Portugal's population is stable at 10.3 million, but it's aging fast. 23% are over 65, projected to hit 35% by 2050. The fertility rate is 1.4, and emigration drains the young. During the 2010s crisis, 500,000 Portuguese emigrated; they're not coming back. Immigration from Brazil, Cape Verde, and more recently Ukraine helps—Portugal granted 400,000 residency permits in 2022-24—but integration is slow, and social services are strained. The pension system is in trouble. The old-age dependency ratio is rising, and contributions are falling. The government has raised the retirement age to 66.5, but it needs to go higher. That's politically toxic.

Public services are crumbling. The NHS (SNS) is underfunded—Portugal spends 6% of GDP on healthcare, versus 9% OECD average. Wait times for surgeries are months long. Nurses and doctors emigrate to France and Germany for better pay. Education is similarly stressed—teacher salaries are low, schools are underfunded, and PISA scores lag Western Europe. Infrastructure investment is below 2% of GDP, inadequate for a country trying to modernize. Roads are decent, thanks to EU funds, but rail is slow and unreliable outside the Lisbon-Porto corridor.

Inequality is moderate by European standards—Gini coefficient 0.32—but regional disparities are stark. Lisbon and Porto thrive; the interior (Alentejo, Beiras) is depopulating and poor. Villages are dying—aging residents, no jobs, no young people. EU funds target rural development, but they can't reverse economic geography. The coast has ports, tourism, and universities; the interior has agriculture and emptiness. It's a Europe-wide pattern, but acute in Portugal.

Bottom line: Portugal is fashionable, growing, and fiscally stable, but it's running into the limits of its model. Tourism and tech are booming, but they don't employ everyone, and they inflate housing costs. Manufacturing has declined, leaving the economy service-heavy and vulnerable. Wages are low relative to living costs, driving emigration. Demographics are dire. Public services are strained. Portugal avoided Greece's catastrophe, but it hasn't built a sustainable, broadly shared growth model. If tourism falters—recession, pandemic, climate change making summers unbearably hot—Portugal's vulnerability is exposed. The next decade will test whether Portugal can translate buzz into broad-based development or whether it becomes a playground for tourists and expats while locals leave. Right now, it's uncomfortably close to the latter.
